Which is why its always good to have the original to fall back on saved in =
better format. A bit like "can't see the flowers for the trees" it depends =
on what viewpoint you take as to what you see/hear or believe. 
=A0
Ok gott=
a split like an atom or I will be late =3D)
=A0
Misty


--- On Sun, 5/10/09=
, April Abercrombie <april@...> wrote:


From: Apr=
il Abercrombie <april@...>
Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] =
File uploading rules
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009=
, 1:12 PM









This is why with digital photos, you can't enlarge them =
without loosing resolution. You can go smaller, but not larger.
=A0
When yo=
u enlarge a digital photo, the photo gets stretched, but the same amount of=
 pixels have to now fill in, so they get larger, which magnifies the pixela=
tion. You end up with a blocky "lo-res" image.=A0You can choose to have it =
"resample", but then you get what RJ described, where the program looks at =
the existing pixels and add pixels that are an average of the surrounding p=
ixels. So you still end up what a grainy, digital looking picture.
=A0
When=
 saving=A0a photo=A0to a compressed format, such as jpeg, you actually loos=
e data, or pixels. The program decides which data to drop to make the file =
smaller. Each time you open and resave, you loose more data.The resolution =
gets worse and worse.
=A0
This is the same thing that happens with audio fi=
les, you loose data each time you save it to a compressed format.
=A0

----=
- Original Message ----- 
From: Rj 
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
Sent: Sun=
day, May 10, 2009 10:54 AM
Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules




=




Pixelization doesn't clean-up the data: it replaces it.=A0 Imagine taki=
ng a picture of a field of flowers, and beginning to add levels or pixeliza=
tion to the picture.=A0 Soon, you would not be able to tell there were flow=
ers there at all.=A0 You would see a lot of colored blocks.

Or in the othe=
r direction, imagine you are looking at a competely randomize bunch of pixe=
s on your screen: a complete screen of truely random static snow.=A0 Pixeli=
zing this, after a while, you would again start to see colored blocks.

Wha=
t's happening is that it is processing an area of the image, taking (for in=
stance) the average value of that entire area, and replacing all the blocks=
 in that area with the average.=A0 In video processing, this would result i=
n a field of multi-colored flowers being replaced by, for instance, a big g=
reyish-bluish block, with no resemblance to flowers.=A0 In the noise exampl=
e, it maybe replace all the random pixels with another big greyish-bluish b=
lock.=A0 If you did not know beforehand what the original picture was, you =
couldn't tell whether your pixelized image was really a field of flowers, a=
 chevy, the sky with clouds, or a random bunch of pixels.

It works the sam=
e with the sound files.=A0 Taking something as complex as speech, and repla=
cing frequencies with their averages, loses the speech the farther you go, =
until you head strange fluctuating square waves.=A0 Doing the same to rando=
m static will eventually produce the same thing.=A0 And random fluctuating =
square waves can sound a bit like speech - or at least, you could have fun =
sharing with each other what you thing they 'sound like'.





--- On Sun, =
5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com> wrote:


From: Misty Dawn <bul=
letbabea@ yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
To: EVP-IT=
C@yahoogroups .com
Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 9:29 AM









I always sa=
ve the whole file in wav format then do my clips as mp3. Then I have the or=
iginal for analysis. 
=A0
As far as pixelization of non sounds/white noise =
whos to say that isnt being manipulated by them as well LOL. Water is a for=
m of white noise. I seem to remember some experiments done with blank tapes=
/film, no recording=A0done yet there were voices/images there. I find it al=
l interesting.
=A0
Just a thought. Ok off to work now!
Misty

--- On Sun, 5=
/10/09, Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com> wrote:


From: Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com>
Su=
bject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
Date=
: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 11:47 AM








Be a bit careful of formats like m=
p3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the sounds though.=A0=A0 While s=
ome formats (like wav) can store the audio very close to the way it was rec=
orded, formats like mp3 compress the file, and in so doing lose some of the=
 sonic details.=A0 This may not be a big deal in music, where the audio is =
fairly clear to begin with.=A0 But with sound sources with a lot of noise (=
like evps), this can not only obscure any real sounds, but pixelize non-sou=
nds (like white noise) and make them start to sound like speech.

So mp3 mi=
ght be good for sharing the data, once you've already formed an opinion bas=
ed on an analysis of the wav file.=A0 But mp3 is not good as a medium for a=
nalysis.=A0 It can lead to many false positives and misinterpretations.

--=

 have trouble use one of the links I posted to help ya out.
=A0
Misty

p>Be a bit careful of formats like mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis=
 of the sounds though.   While some formats (like wav) can store =
the audio very close to the way it was recorded, formats like mp3 compress =
the file, and in so doing lose some of the sonic details.  This may no=
t be a big deal in music, where the audio is fairly clear to begin with.&nb=
sp; But with sound sources with a lot of noise (like evps), this can not on=
ly obscure any real sounds, but pixelize non-sounds (like white noise) and =
make them start to sound like speech.<BR><BR>So mp3 might be good for shari=
ng the data, once you've already formed an opinion based on an analysis of =
the wav file.  But mp3 is not good as a medium for analysis.  It =
can lead to many false positives and misinterpretations.<BR><BR>--- On <B>S=
